channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Proposes Spending $4 Billion on Self-Driving Cars
item.description: A proposal announced by the transportation secretary is meant to accelerate development of autonomous vehicles and remove hurdles for automakers.
item.dc:creator: BILL VLASIC
item.media:description: Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx and a Chevrolet Bolt EV at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit on Thursday, where he announced an initiative on self-driving vehicles.

item.title: Fairfield Ponders a Future Without General Electric
item.description: The company, which moved its headquarters to Fairfield in 1974, is departing for Boston, leaving Connecticut residents worried about the loss of tax revenue and high-paying jobs.
item.dc:creator: KRISTIN HUSSEY
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: General Electric opened its Fairfield campus in 1974.

item.title: As More Pay by Smartphone, Banks Scramble to Keep Up
item.description: A millennial-led shift to digital financial services could upend the consumer banking industry.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR
item.media:description: For young Americans, most relationships with the financial system are electronic.

item.title: Bits Blog: WhatsApp, the Internet Messenger, to Become Free
item.description: The Internet messaging service, owned by Facebook, said it would phase out fees to use the service and experiment with charging companies to talk directly to its almost one billion users worldwide.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Tobias Hase/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Jan Koum, the chief executive and co-founder of WhatsApp, spoke at a conference in Munich on Monday.

item.title: ‘Hack the Dinos’ Helps Paleontologists
item.description: A November contest at the American Museum of Natural History gave programmers a chance to develop ways to manage a glut of data.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG
item.media:credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Programmers at the Hack the Dinos contest at the American Museum of Natural History.

item.title: Tech Tip: Finding Your Way Around GarageBand
item.description: With its ability to play virtual instruments and mix tracks into finished songs, the program can appear intimidating, but there are tutorials right on the iPad.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER
item.media:description: Although it can take some tapping around to find, the GarageBand app for the iPad does come with a built-in manual and help guide.

item.title: Bits Blog: Netflix’s Expansion Attracts Some Unexpected Customers
item.description: Reed Hastings, the video-streaming service’s co-founder, said people on Réunion Island — a small French-governed island off the coast of Madagascar — were some of the first to sign up as new subscribers.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: A surfer off the coast of Réunion Island. The chief of Netflix, Reed Hastings, reports that people from the island were some of the first to sign up as new subscribers as the company expands globally.

item.title: Strat-O-Matic Builds Out Its Digital Game Roster
item.description: Baseball Daily, a new digital simulation game to be unveiled by Strat-O-Matic on Monday, trades in dice and card decks for daily stats and proprietary algorithms.
item.dc:creator: STUART MILLER
item.media:credit: Heather Walsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hal Richman, right, founder of Strat-O-Matic. On Monday, the company will unveil a new baseball simulation game.

item.title: Advertising: Marketing in the Moments, to Reach Customers Online
item.description: One trend in mobile advertising is to focus on those fleeting times when customers have a need for something, or might be receptive to a pitch.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. HOF
item.media:description: Campari America used Kiip, a San Francisco firm that places ads in mobile apps, to promote its Skyy vodka.

item.title: Netflix’s Opaque Disruption Annoys Rivals on TV
item.description: Netflix’s refusal to disclose ratings has led to mounting frustration from traditional television industry executives.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN
item.media:description: “The methodology and the measurement and the data itself don’t reflect any sense of reality of anything that we keep track of,” said Ted Sarandos, chief content officer at Netflix.

item.title: Education Technology Graduates From the Classroom to the Boardroom
item.description: Much of the money pouring into ed tech is going to start-ups focused on corporate training or professional skills, creating greater financing hurdles for companies that develop apps for school use.
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tory Patterson, co-founder of Owl Ventures, which invests in ed tech start-ups.

item.title: For Now, Self-Driving Cars Still Need Humans
item.description: Vehicles are increasingly able to do routine tasks, but the problem vexing the automobile industry is how to keep drivers ready to take over the wheel when necessary.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:credit: Elizabeth D. Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A test ride in a prototype of an autonomous Nissan vehicle. Like the Tesla, the new Nissan models will still require human oversight.

item.title: European Antitrust Chief Takes Swipe at Privacy Issue
item.description: Margrethe Vestager’s warning shot comes ahead of a Jan. 31 deadline for Europe and the United States to reach a new data-sharing agreement.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust chief, speaking on Sunday at the DLD conference, a gathering of digital executives and policy makers.

item.title: Bits Blog: Jawbone Raises $165 Million at Half Its Last Valuation
item.description: Jawbone, the start-up that makes wearable devices, became the latest private company to raise money at a lower valuation than before.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and KATIE BENNER

item.title: Uber Not to Blame for Rise in Manhattan Traffic Congestion, Report Says
item.description: The report, based on a study conducted after Uber and Mayor Bill de Blasio clashed over his plan to cap the number of for-hire vehicles on New York City’s streets, recommended against such a limit.
item.dc:creator: EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:description: While app-based car services like Uber had contributed to overall traffic in Manhattan, a report said, they “did not drive the recent increase in congestion.”

item.title: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Not-So-‘Basic’ Shift in Start-Ups
item.description: Apple Music gains ground, an initiative on self-driving cars and a sensible move from Foursquare — with a twist of “cool-kid” slang.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC
item.media:description: Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx views a 2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. He announced an initiative to streamline the rules for self-driving cars.

item.title: Foursquare Raises $45 Million, Cutting Its Valuation Nearly in Half
item.description: The company, which is also shaking up its executive ranks, is focused on its data-based advertising and developer businesses.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC
item.media:description: Foursquare executives, from left: Steven Rosenblatt, president; Dennis Crowley, executive chairman; and Jeff Glueck, chief executive.

item.title: Alphabet Shakes Up Its Robotics Division
item.description: The holding company that owns Google is moving the unit from a stand-alone division to a piece of X research and putting a new focus on robots.
item.dc:creator: CONOR DOUGHERTY
item.media:description: Astro Teller, who runs Google’s X research division, at the SXSW Interactive gathering last year.

item.title: News Analysis: In Online Dating, ‘Sextortion’ and Scams
item.description: Online romance scams bilk people out of more than $200 million a year, but humans’ hard-wiring makes the frauds hard to stop.
item.dc:creator: KATE MURPHY

item.title: The New Old Age: F.T.C.’s Lumosity Penalty Doesn’t End Brain Training Debate
item.description: The federal agency said the company couldn’t back up its claims of helping with cognitive impairment, but experts on both sides weighed in.
item.dc:creator: PAULA SPAN
